Incident Investigation Procedures:
 
An incident investigation program is in place at the plant to review incidents and implement any identified improvement(s) to reduce future potential for new incidents to occur.
Compliance Audit Procedures:
At least every three years a full program audit is conducted.

D.	Five-Year Accident History

There have been no accidents as defined by EPA Risk Management in the past 5 years that have resulted in a death, injury, or significant property damage on site or off-site death, injury, evacuation, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

E.	Description of the Emergency Response Program

An emergency action program has been implemented at the facility. This program contains procedures describing how the facility will respond to chlorine releases and other emergencies, including evacuation procedures. The program has been coordinated with local fire department officials.

The emergency action program is based upon federal guidelines as they apply to this facility. The emergency action plan includes procedures for notification of the local fire authority, local emergency response agencies, and notification of any potentially affected neighbors. The facility emergency action plan is based on all known applicable regulations and requirements. The emergency action plan has been discussed with the Winona Fire Department and other agencies involved with response. Representatives of the Winona Fire Department visit the facility on an annual basis.
F.	Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Identification of opportunities and changes to improve safety is part of the culture of this facility. In addition to the programs mentioned above, the following changes are planned to improve safety:

and Regulated Substances Handled

Chlorine is the only substance covered by the Accidental Release Prevention Regulations handled at this facility.

C.	Description of the Accidental Release Prevention Program
 
The facility has an accident release prevention program that complies with Occupational Safety and Health Act's Process Safety Management Standard and EPA's Risk Management Program Rule. The prevention program consists of the following elements:

Employee Participation Program:
The facility has an overall safety program that includes employee awareness and training to minimize the potential for an accident or incident involving the chlorine equipment.
Process Safety Information:
Chlorine equipment manuals and plant design technical specifications including piping diagrams are on file.
Process Hazard Analysis:
A process hazard analysis (PHA) has been conducted on the chlorine system. 
Operating Procedures:
Written Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) were prepared to provide the basis for proper and safe operation of the chlorine system.
Training Program:
An operator training program is designed to ensure that the systems are operated by qualified personnel.
Contractor Safety Program:
Contractors that are used to work on or adjacent to the refrigeration system are pre- qualified based upon their knowledge of chlorine systems, understanding of applicable codes and standards, and their demonstrated ability to work safely. Each of these contractors is evaluated from a safety perspective.
Pre-Startup Safety Review Procedures:
See comments under Management of Change Mechanical Integrity Program:
The facility has a program for maintenance designed to maintain the on-going integrity of the system.
Hot Work Permit Procedures:
The facility has implemented a Hot Work permit program including training.

Executive Summary

The City of Winona Water Treatment facility located in Winona, MN is a municipal water treatment facility. The facility has chlorine which is used for water sanitization purposes. The City of Winona has a strong commitment to operate the facility in a safe and responsible manner.

The chlorine is contained in a closed system designed to remain inside the piping and vessels. Chlorine is injected into the municipal water supply at the facility and fully consumed once injected. 

Chlorine is classified by EPA as a toxic chemical and it is necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling it to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the health threat to our own workers, and reduce the threat to nearby members of the community. It is the City of Winona policy to adhere to all Federal and State rules and regulations. Safety depends upon the manner in which chlorine is handled, use of safety devices inherent in the design of this facility, and training of facility personnel.

A.	Accident Release Prevention and Emergency Policies

This facility complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule, OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard and with all applicable State codes and regulations.

The City of Winona takes many precautions to prevent or minimize accidental releases of chlorine from the treatment system. These precautions include safety controls and alarms which are designed to identify and prevent potentially unsafe conditions like pressure increases that could cause a system failure. The facility also has a maintenance program designed to maintain the on-going integrity of the systems, a training program designed to ensure that the system is operated by qualified personnel and emergency action procedures that enable trained personnel to respond quickly to system upsets and releases.

The City of Winona Water Superintendent is responsible for the management of the chlorine safety programs.
